questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician with concerns about her behavior. She reports that she has been experiencing irresistible urges to set fires, which she has acted upon several times in the past few months. She feels relief after setting the fires but later feels guilty and ashamed. She has not experienced any legal consequences yet but is worried about her safety and the safety of others. Based on her symptoms, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Pyromania

Explanation:

  • • Explanation :
  • • Option A. Kleptomania is an impulse control disorder characterized by the recurrent and irresistible urge to steal items that are not needed for personal use or monetary value.
  • • Option A. Kleptomania
  • • impulse control disorder
  • • recurrent and irresistible urge to steal items
  • • Option B. Intermittent explosive disorder involves recurrent episodes of impulsive, aggressive behavior that is disproportionate to the precipitating stressor .
  • • Option B. Intermittent explosive disorder
  • • recurrent episodes of impulsive, aggressive behavior
  • • disproportionate to the precipitating stressor
  • • Option D. Compulsive sexual behavior disorder is characterized by a persistent pattern of failure to control intense , repetitive sexual impulses or urges, resulting in repetitive sexual behavior .
  • • Option D. Compulsive sexual behavior disorder
  • • persistent pattern of failure to control intense
  • • repetitive sexual impulses
  • • repetitive sexual behavior
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Pyromania is an impulse control disorder characterized by an irresistible urge to set fires, tension before the act , and relief or pleasure afterward . It is distinct from other impulse control disorders like kleptomania (compulsive stealing) and intermittent explosive disorder (sudden aggressive outbursts), as well as from compulsive sexual behavior disorder.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman is brought to the psychiatrist by her family after she was caught shoplifting at a local store. She has a history of similar incidents. She expresses guilt and shame about her actions and reports that she experiences an increasing sense of tension before the act, and relief and gratification afterwards. The items stolen are not of personal use or monetary value to her. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Kleptomania

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. Bipolar disorder: While impulse control can be a problem in the manic phases of bipolar disorder , the recurrent nature of the stealing and the specific pattern of tension and relief described in the vignette is more characteristic of kleptomania.
  • • Option A. Bipolar disorder:
  • • impulse control can be a problem in the manic phases of bipolar disorder
  • • recurrent nature of the stealing
  • • specific pattern of tension
  • • Option B. Antisocial personality disorder: People with an antisocial personality disorder may engage in stealing , but it is usually for personal gain , and they do not typically experience tension before the act or relief afterward in the same way someone with kleptomania does.
  • • Option B. Antisocial personality disorder:
  • • antisocial personality disorder may engage in stealing
  • • usually for personal gain
  • • do not typically experience tension
  • • Option D. Generalized anxiety disorder : This disorder is characterized by chronic, excessive worry about a variety of topics , but it does not involve the impulse control issues seen in kleptomania.
  • • Option D. Generalized anxiety disorder
  • • chronic, excessive worry about a variety of topics

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

There is an impulse to steal followed by a feeling of increasing tension . After stealing, there is a sense of relief or even gratification. After some time, the individual feels guilt.

questions.text: A 24-year-old man is brought to the psychiatrist by his family due to recurrent episodes of intense anger and aggressive outbursts over the past 6 months. These episodes occur without provocation and involve verbal tirades, throwing objects, and physical aggression. He feels a sense of relief after the outbursts but later expresses remorse. His family reports that these aggressive episodes are out of proportion to the situation and are concerned about his safety and the safety of others. The patient has no history of substance abuse, and there is no evidence of any underlying mood or psychotic disorders. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Borderline personality disorder: This disorder is characterized by instability in relationships, self-image, and affect, as well as impulsive behaviour . While individuals with borderline personality disorder can have episodes of intense anger, the overall pattern of instability in various areas of life is not described in the vignette.
  • • Option A. Borderline personality disorder:
  • • disorder is characterized by instability in relationships, self-image, and affect, as well as impulsive behaviour
  • • Option B. Antisocial personality disorder: This disorder involves a pervasive pattern of disregard for and violation of the rights of others . While aggression can be a feature of antisocial personality disorder, the episodic nature of the aggression described in the vignette is more characteristic of IED.
  • • Option B. Antisocial personality disorder:
  • • disorder involves a pervasive pattern of disregard for and violation of the rights of others
  • • Option D. Conduct disorder: This is a disorder seen in children and adolescents that involves a persistent pattern of behavior that violates the rights of others or societal norms . While aggression is a feature of conduct disorder, the age of the patient in the vignette makes this diagnosis less likely.
  • • Option D. Conduct disorder:
  • • disorder seen in children and adolescents that involves a persistent pattern of behavior that violates the rights of others or societal norms
